tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"his faithful love for me will never end"
"The redeemed" refers to the people whom Yahweh has saved. AT: "those whom Yahweh has saved" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
This means to tell others about something. AT: "tell about what Yahweh has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: from the hand of the enemy
tn.text: Here "hand" refers to power. AT: "from the power of the enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: from the east ... and from the south
tn.text: Here the four directions are given to emphasize that he gather them from everywhere. AT: "from every direction" or "from every part of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: from the east and from the west, from the north and from the south
tn.text: This describes the places that Yahweh gather his people from. AT: "he has gathered them from the east and from the west, from the north and from the south" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"Some people wandered"
"on a road that was in the desert"
"that they could live in"

tn.ref: Then they called out to Yahweh in their trouble
tn.text: It is implied that they are praying to Yahweh so that he will help them. AT: "Then they prayed to Yahweh to help them in their trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"difficulties" or "afflictions"

tn.ref: Oh that people would praise Yahweh for his covenant faithfulness
tn.text: "Let people praise Yahweh because he faithfully loves them" or "People should praise Yahweh because of his faithful love." Here the word "Oh" is used to convey a strong desire for people to praise him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
"people" or "humans"

tn.ref: For he satisfies the longings of those who are thirsty
tn.text: "For he gives water to those who desire it—to those who are thirsty"

tn.ref: and the desires of those who are hungry he fills up with good things
tn.text: "and to those who are very hungry and desire food, he give them good things to eat"
"for all people"
It is implied that these are people that Yahweh has rescued. AT: "Yahweh also rescued people who sat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Both "darkness" and "gloom" have basically the same meaning and are used to emphasize how dark the prison was. AT: "in complete darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: they had rebelled against God's word ... rejected the instruction of the Most High
tn.text: These phrases have similar meanings and emphasize how much they had rebelled again God, which is why they had been imprisoned. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: He humbled their hearts through hardship
tn.text: Here the heart represents a person, but specifically his will. AT: "He humbled them by allowing them to suffer hardship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "trouble" or 2) "hard labor."

tn.ref: they stumbled and there was no one to help them up
tn.text: The word "stumbled" refers to times when these people got into very difficult situations. AT: "they got into trouble and there was no one to help them out of it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Then they called out to Yahweh in their trouble
tn.text: It is implied that they are praying to Yahweh so that he will help them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:004|107:6]]. AT: "Then they prayed to Yahweh to help them in their trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"difficulties" or "afflictions." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:004|107:6]]
Here David describes Yahweh saving them from their distress as if their distress were a physical place that he was bringing them out of. AT: "he saved" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Yahweh brought those in prison"

Both "darkness" and "gloom" have basically the same meaning and are used to emphasize how dark the prison was. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:008|107:10]]. AT: "complete darkness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: Oh that people would praise Yahweh for his covenant faithfulness
tn.text: "Let people praise Yahweh because he faithfully loves them" or "People should praise Yahweh because of his faithful love." Here the word "Oh" is used to convey a strong desire for people to praise him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:008|107:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
"because he"

tn.ref: For he has broken the gates of bronze and cut through the bars of iron
tn.text: Both of these phrases describe Yahweh freeing his people from prison and are used to emphasize that Yahweh truly freed them. AT: "He freed his people from prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: They were foolish in their rebellious ways
tn.text: "They were foolish in the way they rebelled against Yahweh"
"and they suffered." Specifically they were afflicted by becoming sick. AT: "and they became sick" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: they came close to the gates of death
tn.text: Here the act of "dying" is described as a place, "the gates of death" AT: "they almost died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Then they called out to Yahweh in their trouble
tn.text: It is implied that they are praying to Yahweh so that he will help them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:004|107:6]]. AT: "Then they prayed to Yahweh to help them in their trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: He sent his word and healed them
tn.text: Here David describes Yahweh speaking as sending his words as if they were a messenger. Possible meanings are `1) "He commanded for them to be healed and they were healed" or 2) "He encouraged them and healed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Oh that people would praise Yahweh for his covenant faithfulness
tn.text: "Let people praise Yahweh because he faithfully loves them" or "People should praise Yahweh because of his faithful love." Here the word "Oh" is used to convey a strong desire for people to praise him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:008|107:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
"that show that they are thankful"
"by singing about them"
They would sail to places and buy and sell things with the people there. AT: "selling things in cities far away" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he commanded and aroused the windstorm that stirs up the seas
tn.text: "he commanded the wind and caused it become a great windstorm that stirred up the sea"
a strong wind, like the wind that accompanies a strong rain storm

Here David describes the winds causing the waves to become high as if the wind was an object fiercely stirring something. AT: "that caused the waves of the sea to become very high" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They reached up to the sky; they went down to the depths
tn.text: This describes the ships rising and falling with the waves. The extremes of rising to the sky and falling to the depths are an exaggeration to express how horrible the windstorm was. AT: "their ships would rise very high on the waves and then they would fall very low between the waves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Their lives melted away in distress
tn.text: This idiom describes the sailors' great fear. AT: "The men were terrified and greatly distressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "at their wit's end" means that they did not know what to do. AT: "and they did not know what to do" or "they had no idea what to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Then they called out to Yahweh in their trouble
tn.text: It is implied that they are praying to Yahweh so that he will help them. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:004|107:6]]. AT: "Then they prayed to Yahweh to help them in their trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "they" refers to the sailors.
"He made the wind stop"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "he made the waves still" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"he guided them"
"to the harbor where they wanted to go"

tn.ref: Oh that people would praise Yahweh for his covenant faithfulness
tn.text: "Let people praise Yahweh because he faithfully loves them" or "People should praise Yahweh because of his faithful love." Here the word "Oh" is used to convey a strong desire for people to praise him. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:107:008|107:8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: praise him in the council of the elders
tn.text: "when the elders sit together." The elders sat together to discuss issues in the community and to make decisions for the community.
"Yahweh makes"

tn.ref: because of the wickedness of its people
tn.text: "because the people that live there are wicked"

tn.ref: He turns the wilderness into a pool of water and dry land into springs of water
tn.text: Both of these phrases have similar meaning and emphasize how Yahweh makes water appear in the wilderness. AT: "He make springs and lakes in land that used to be desert" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

The word "there" refers to the places where Yahweh made springs and lakes appear.  Also, the phrase "the hungry" refers to people who are hungry. AT: "Yahweh makes people who are hungry live there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"to plant vineyards in"

tn.ref: and to bring in an abundant harvest
tn.text: "so that they can produce a plentiful harvest"
"so that their people are very numerous"

tn.ref: He does not let their cattle decrease in number
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "He keeps their cattle very numerous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
The word "They" refers to the people who were hungry that Yahweh had settled in the land. This sentence describes how they were before Yahweh settled them in the land.

tn.ref: They were diminished and brought low
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Their leaders diminished their number and brought them low" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"became fewer in number"
This means to be humiliated. AT: "humiliated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here David speaks of Yahweh showing contempt for the leaders as if contempt were a liquid he poured out on them. AT: "shows contempt for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"the nobles." This refers to the leaders who oppressed the people. AT: "the leaders who oppressed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"where people never go"
"But Yahweh"
This refers to needy people. AT: "needy people" or "poor people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: cares for his families like a flock
tn.text: Here David compares how Yahweh cares for his people to how a shepherd cares for his sheep. Possible meanings are 1) "makes the number of people in their families increase like flocks" or 2) "takes care of them like a shepherd cares for his sheep" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to people who live in an upright way. AT: "Upright people" or "People who do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
Here wicked people are referred to as "wickedness." AT: "all wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This means to not say anything in response. AT: "has nothing to say against Yahweh in reply" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to think about these things. AT: "think about these things" or "remember these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
